III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4109 Program Statement
Section (1) An institution shall have and follow a current written
Description program statement which specifically addresses all the
following:
1

(c) Policies and procedures pertaining to admission, care,
safety, and supervision, methods for addressing residents'
needs, implementation of treatment plans, and discharge of
residents.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth A is not allowed to call her worker.
Investigation Interviews:
I left a voicemail for Complainant on 3/19/25 and 4/2/25. I have
not received a return call.
Youth A was interviewed face to face at the facility on 4/2/25.
Youth A reported she has never had an issue with calling her
worker. Youth A reported she usually doesn’t request to contact
her worker due to her worker coming up monthly.
Therapist was interviewed via telephone on 4/7/25. Therapist
reported Youth A hasn’t requested to call her worker, but if she did
she could call her. Therapist reported Youth A will normally ask to
contact her mother.
Worker reported via email on 4/11/25, that she has never had a
difficult time getting ahold of Youth A and Youth A has not
complained to her about this.
Documents Reviewed:
• I reviewed the Visitation and Communication policy. It does
allow for worker phone calls and visits.
Analysis The agency is compliant with this rule. Youth A, Therapist, and
Worker all reported there has not been an issue contacting
Worker.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4142 Health services; policies and procedures
Section (1) An institution shall establish and follow written health
Description service policies and procedures addressing all of the
following:
(a) Routine and emergency medical, and dental, and
behavioral health care.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
2

Allegation Youth A is currently taking Vyvanse, and they increased her
dosage without consent.
Investigation Interviews:
I left a voicemail for Complainant on 3/19/25 and 4/2/25. I have
not received a return call.
Administrator was interviewed face to face at the facility on
3/19/25. Administrator reported all guardians sign a document at
intake allowing the agency to change dosage of medications
throughout the youth’s stay. Administrator reported Youth A’s
medication has not changed since intake.
Youth A was interviewed face to face at the facility on 4/2/25.
Youth A reported she takes Vyvanse. Youth A reported she went
to her most recent medication review and asked for increase in
Vyvanse dosage. Youth A reported her psychiatrist completed
this.
Therapist was interviewed via telephone on 4/7/25. Therapist
reported she is not a part of changing medication. Therapist
reported they have consent forms for all youth that are on
medication that allows them to administer medication and change
dosage of their current medications. Therapist reported if the
agency changes their medication, then a new consent form would
need to be completed.
Documents Reviewed:
• I reviewed the Psychotropic Medication Informed Consent
document. It was signed on 10/1/24 by Parent. Vyvanse is
listed as a medication. The form does state new consent
will be completed if a new medication is prescribed.
• I reviewed the Psychiatric Care Policy. The psychiatrist is
permitted to change dosage and medications, and written
consent will be gathered before medication is dispensed.
• I reviewed the “Psychiatric Follow Up Note” dated 3/7/25.
Vyvanse was increased from 30mg to 40mg.
Analysis The agency is compliant with this rule. The agency has a consent
form signed by Parent and the medication Vyvanse is listed as a
current and approved medication. The agency policy and consent
form both document that medication changes will require new
consent forms but not dosage change.
3

CONSULTATION:
The agency may want to add on their Psychotropic Medication
Informed Consent form a statement that clearly states, “dosages
can be changed.” Not all guardians may be able to distinguish
between medication and dosage changes.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4158 Intervention standards and prohibitions
Section (1) A child caring institution shall establish and follow written
Description policies and procedures that prohibit the following forms of
intervention:
(b) Denial of any essential program service as punishment.
These include, but are not limited to, the following:
(ii) Family time or any type of communications with family.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Therapist is threatening to remove Youth A's home pass if she is
too emotional on her home pass. Therapist is threatening Youth A
that she will not be able to talk to Parent.
Investigation Interviews:
I left a voicemail for Complainant on 3/19/25 and 4/2/25. I have
not received a return call.
Administrator was interviewed face to face on 3/19/25. She
reported they do not discipline children by taking away home
visits. It is expected children will have emotions on their home
visits. Administrator reported Youth A had her first 12-day home
pass on 3/15/25. She was supposed to return on 3/15/25 at
8:00pm, but didn’t return until 3/16/25. Youth A had reported to
her upon return that she was anxious while at home. Due to this
Parent told her, because of her anxiety she needed to go to a
crisis center. Administrator reported she did not tell Youth A she
couldn’t go home again because of this. Administrator reported
Youth A’s worker dictates the home passes.
Youth A was interviewed face to face at the facility on 4/2/25.
Youth A reported she went on her first home pass on 3/15/25.
Youth A reported she went to a crisis center that evening, then
went home with her mother. The following day they went back to
the crisis center around 11am and then went to the agency. Youth
A reported she has never been told by anyone at the facility
including Therapist that she would lose her home passes if she
4

showed too much emotion. Youth A reported she was very
anxious on her first home pass and was thinking that these things
could happen. Youth A reported Therapist never stated she
couldn’t talk to Parent. Youth A reported Therapist had a
conversation with her and Parent concerning communication while
at the facility. Parent had told Youth A her dog passed away on a
phone call and Therapist told Parent these topics should be
discussed with her before spoken on a phone so support can be
provided.
Therapist was interviewed via telephone on 4/7/25. Therapist
reported she has never told Youth A that her home passes would
be taken from her if she showed too many emotions. Therapist
reported she has spoken to Parent on different occasions
concerning phone calls. Therapist reported she went over that all
major topics should be discussed with Therapist before spoken to
Youth A on the phone so that if any type of support is needed for
Youth A, she will be there to help her though it. Therapist reported
Parent has told Youth A over the phone things that has caused
anxiety in Youth A. Therapist noted these conversations included
an abusive individual living in their home and Youth A needing to
find a different place to live when she leaves placement. Therapist
reported Parent told Youth A that her dog died. This was another
incident where Parent should have spoken to her first, so they are
not caught off guard. Therapist reported she had a phone call after
this with Youth A and Parent on the phone stating the importance
of talking to her before announcing these things to Youth A.
Therapist never stated she was not going to let Parent talk to
Youth A.
Analysis The agency is compliant with this rule. Youth A reported Therapist
never told her she wouldn’t be able to go home. She
acknowledged these were her anxieties. Both Therapist and Youth
A reported there was no threat of removing phone calls to Parent.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
5

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
